newsitem.title: CANADA: Placer faces Kazakh claim, slim risk seen.
newsitem.headline: Placer faces Kazakh claim, slim risk seen.

text.p: The Kazakhstan government has made a counterclaim against Placer Dome Inc for US$270 million before an arbitration panel considering a dispute between them, but analysts on Friday saw little chance of Kazakhstan prevailing.

Placer has been trying to recover a US$35 million deposit paid to the Kazakhstan government for the Vasilkovskoye gold project. Placer in 1995 decided to drop the project and said its deposit should have been refunded.
An accord between Placer and the government stipulated that any disputes would be put to a London arbitration panel. That panel is now weighing submissions by the two sides.

A Placer spokesman said Friday that Kazakhstan submitted its arguments to the panel about two months ago. It contended then that instead of owing Placer money, Placer should pay Kazakhstan US$270 million. That amount is what the Canadian company would have paid if it went ahead with the Vasilkovskoye project.
Placer contends the Kazakhstan claim is far-fetched and several mining analysts agreed.
"What a load of rubbish," said one Toronto analyst, who asked not to be identified, about the Kazakhstan claim.
"Kazakhstan is trying to build a wall of defense, saying we'll sue you. But I don't put much value on what Kazakhstan says. Look at who is out money over this matter, and that is Placer."
Placer Dome stock was done 0.60 at 25.30 on the Toronto Stock Exchange. Analysts said a front-page article about the Kazakhstan claim in Canada's Financial Post newspaper alarmed some investors.
